Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Ultra-Rapid Freezing to Maintain Stem Cell Developmental Potential in Rainbow Trout
Award.AbstractNarration:
The establishment of novel technologies for the long-term storage of fish genetic resources has become critical as aquatic species around the world are experiencing rapid declines due to overexploitation and global climate change. This project will examine an innovative area of reproductive stem cell biology to investigate optimal conditions for vitrification of spermatogonial stem cells from Rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss). Vitrification involves ultra-rapid cooling that results in instant solidification of the cell without crystallization. Development of a vitrification protocol is desirable since vitrification is fast and the process avoids trauma to cells by eliminating intracellular ice formation and instead creates a glass-like (vitreous) state, resulting in higher cell survival. This study will be conducted at the Tokyo University of Marine Sciences and Technology in Tokyo, Japan in collaboration with and under the supervision of Dr. Goro Yoshizaki, a renowned expert in fish reproductive stem cell biology. The proposed study will provide insight into fundamental aspects of stem cell cryobiology and could lead to real-world application of an inexpensive, economical method for preserving fish genetic resources for the conservation of endangered fish and aquaculture purposes.

The proposed experiments for this project will use Gfp-vasa+ transgenic rainbow trout to 1) determine the effects of the vitrification process on spermatogonial stem cell survival and 2) investigate the functionality of vitrified spermatogonial stem cells. Stem cell survival will be quantified by using flow cytometry, which will separate cell populations into viable or non-viable based on fluorescence patterns. A germ cell transplantation assay will be utilized to determine if the viable vitrified stem cells retain their functionality potential to colonize and proliferate in recipients. This research will improve understanding of the complex effects of cryopreservation and vitrification on stem cell function while providing the information necessary to successfully implement stem cell research as a novel artificial reproductive technology method to maximize genetic diversity for the conservation of threatened aquatic species. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science (JSPS).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The development and implementation of new tools for conservation biology is essential for species at risk of extinction. Cryobanking of reproductive cells and tissues in conjunction with stem cell biotechnologies offers an innovative assisted reproductive tool for the conservation of endangered species. The techniques available for long-term preservation of fish genetic resources are limited to live rearing and sperm cryopreservation. Development of a vitrification protocol is desirable since vitrification is fast and the process avoids trauma to cells by eliminating intracellular ice formation and instead creates a glass-like (vitreous) state, resulting in high viability. We investigated optimal conditions for vitrification of spermatogonial stem cells from Rainbow trout (Oncorhynchus mykiss). Gfp-vasa+ transgenic immature male rainbow trout gonads were used to 1) develop an optimized vitrification protocol for spermatogonial stem cell survival and 2) investigate the functionality of vitrified spermatogonial stem cells. Stem cell survival was quantified with flow cytometry, which identified cell populations as viable or non-viable based on fluorescence patterns. A trout germ cell transplantation assay was utilized to determine if the viable vitrified stem cells retain their functional potential to colonize allogenic recipient genital ridges. Vitrified cells were transplanted into 32-day post fertilization wild-type rainbow trout larvae to examine the colonization efficiencies of transplanted spermatogonia. The viability of spermatogonia stem cells vitrified in 0.2M sucrose (82.85% ± 8.89, mean ± SEM) was higher than those vitrified in 0.4M sucrose and 0.2M or 0.4M trehalose (68.84±0.91, 71.32%±15.84, 68.74±5.13, n=3). The effects of permeating cryoprotectants dissolved in 0.2M sucrose and 3.3x extender was also assessed. The viability of spermatogonia obtained from a 15% (vol/vol) DMSO and 15% (vol/vol) Ethylene Glycol (65.14%±13.16) was higher than 30% (vol/vol) DMSO, Ethylene Glycol, and Propylene Glycol individually (60.79%±8.67, 18.28%± 1.74, and 38.79%±4.92, n=3). Finally the effects of non-permeating cryoprotectants were evaluated. Gonads vitrified in solution containing 20% (vol/vol) FBS (66.14%±20.56) had higher viability than spermatogonia obtained from vitrification media containing either 2% (vol/vol) egg yolk or 15% (wt/vol) BSA (66.13%±19.71 and 48.64%±15.59). Overall gonads vitrified in the solution containing 0.2M sucrose, 20% (vol/vol) Fetal Bovine Serum, 3.3x extender with 15% Dimethyl Sulfoxide and 15% Ethylene Glycol was utilized for the transplantation assay. Vitrified spermatogonia transplant efficiencies were compared with those of freshly prepared germ cell. Colonization efficiencies of vitrified cells did not significantly differ from freshly prepared cells (51.85% and 65% respectively). The viability of SSCs did not decrease with length of storage time (30+ days storage).  A combination of spermatogonial vitrification and transplantation provides an inexpensive, convenient approach to preservation and magnification of fish genetic resources for aquaculture and conservation of endangered fish. Future studies will determine whether vitrified spermatogonia cells retain their potential to proliferate and differentiate into female and male germ cells after transplantation.

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2016
Modified by: Tawny N Scanlan

Cryobanking of reproductive cells and tissues in conjunction with stem cell biotechnologies offers an innovative assisted reproductive tool for the conservation of endangered species. The techniques available for long-term preservation of fish genetic resources are limited to live rearing and sperm cryopreservation.
